THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 29, 1883

KAT PORTAGE.

The trouble between Ontario and Manitoba in reference to the Disputed Portage has caused further alarm. A very large part of the trouble has been of purely imaginary character, and seems to have had its existence principally in the mind of Mr. Young, who has corresponded who appears to have concocted their story without having any actual knowledge of the circumstances. Ontario has taken hold of the reins with a firm hand, and the proposed alliance would result in quiet possession, as Mr. Young does not seem to be disposed to cause further trouble, unless the judgment of the Courts in some of the cases now pending should be in favor of Manitoba or rather of the Dominion.

INDIAN EXPENDITURE.

All the world knows by what bypaths and crooked ways I met this crown, And I myself know well how valuable some It lay upon my brow.

The Globe draws attention to the fact that under Mr. Dewdney's regime the expenditure under the head of "Indian Grants" has been increasing at the rate of over $200,000 per annum. The expenditure in the year ending March 31st, 1884, was $1,644,474, of which only $145,474 went to the Provinces of Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island collectively, while $331,874 went to the Columbian and the remainder, $899,796, went to Manitoba and the North West Territories. The annual increase was $222,079, leaving $877,726 for the Province. Of this there were spent in providing supplies distribution $50,451; in "general expenses" $89,972; in provisions $14,453; and in farm maintenance $37,888. These sums are insignificant, large expenses that are incurred in procuring supplies and might well occupy the attention of the Public Accounts Committee of the House of Commons. The public have some interest in knowing how the money was expended.

TECHNICAL POINTS.

The Ontario Cabinet is composed almost exclusively of members of the legal profession, and in connection with many adverse criticisms to which the administration became inevitable, answer is always, "That so many of the questions which continually arise are of such a legal character as to require the attention of a lawyer." This has been the answer given to objections in the only three departments with which serious fault has been found, viz., the Attorney General and Licence Acts. Strangely enough, no fault has been found with the branches which are under the department of the lawman member. It is now announced that the new Provincial Treasurer, semi-officially announced at the time of Mr. Young's appointment will take place. This fact, together with the legal character of many of the questions continually arising in connection with the administration of the Licence Act rendered the position of the Hon. Mr. Hardy to that of the new Provincial Treasurer, semi-officially announced at the time of Mr. Young's appointment will take place.

CHOLESA IN EGYPT.

The ravages of the cholera in Africa and Asia and its march towards the west affords reasonable cause for apprehension, if not alarm. At the time of the former visit of this much dreaded epidemic, the disease was prevalent in many parts of the older Provinces were few and far between, yet the awful scourge passed few, if any, of them by. In these days of steam navigation and rapid transportation, the spread of the disease is more rapid than in the old days. In Egypt, at the present moment, the epidemic is working terrible havoc, and some twelve thousand deaths have already occurred within the last three weeks, as many five hundred being reported in one day. With the close relations existing between the stricken country and Great Britain, it is little wonder that the authorities there have become somewhat alarmed at the prospect of a visitation of the epidemic, and are acting upon the principle that an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of cure. The people of Ontario are also advised to take time by the forelock. Local municipalities are being urged by the Ontario Bureau of Health to take proper sanitary measures to prevent the disease. The people of Canada will perhaps be as easy controlled as it is amongst many other diseases which were at one time thought to be incurable. There is not much this continent can do to help the fight, the rocking corruption and the oppressive heat incident to those eastern countries where such diseases have their natural birthplace. But if proper sanitary precautions are taken by the people of Europe and America, the cholera may be confined to its eastern home.

EDITORIAL NOTES.

At a meeting of the Clan-na-Gael Association at Chicago, Congressmen Finney emphatically declared the approval of the members of the latter body. The Speaker Cox is being put forward as a candidate for the Speakership of the next House of Representatives. The Democrats, having control of the House, will have many advantages. Mr. Cox claims to have majority of Democrats on his side. Randall, the last Speaker, is also a candidate, and claims that the caucus will be in his favor. In the event that Randall becomes elected Speaker, he will be in a position of being the Democratic nominee for the Presidency will be increased. Sunset Cox lectured in Toronto once or twice, and is rather a hot-headed fellow.

There are going a few lords and dukes and men of high degree coming to this country just now. Lords and dukes and men of high degree would make fairly good immigrants if they took up land and came to cultivate the waste places of the earth. But this they will not do. They come out here for purposes of speculation. They want to buy land to sell again, making a difference of several per cent. This being the case, the country is really not in want of lords and dukes and men of high degree, but would be a good thing if the Government would provide the sale of land cheap in the North West to any but those who intend to cultivate it.

The Northcote arrived out from the mouth of the River Missouri early morning. She had been away from this place for some time, having to wait for a boat to help her over. Her freight was partly for Mr. Young & Co.

ITEMS OF INTEREST.

A heavy frost was reported in Michi-
gan last week.

Miss Emma Gordon's sister, in Kingston lecturing.

Fish House & Hall, lumbermen at Dalhousie, Missisquoi Bay, Quebec.

The Nile flood from Assuan to Cairo, on August 14th, numbered 274.

Hamilton Oddfellows have represented their hall at a cost of $500.

The Pope has sent an autograph letter to His Majesty regarding the imprison-
ment.

Considerable snow has been brought to the Belleville district by violent storms.

Prince Edward Island is a favorite summer resort. All the hotels are over-
crowded.

A lad named German tried to steal a horse from a train at Montreal, and was captured.

A scheme is talked of for the establish-
ment of a daily line of steamers between King-
ston and Montreal.

All the governors have consented to the establishment of Sir Zorilda, who would be president of Spain.

A sixteen month old son of a farmer on the Island of Anticosti, fell into a pit hole and was drowned.

There was a great storm in Switzer-
land August 13th. Three villages were set afire by lightning.

Fishing on the coast of Labrador is ex-
ceptionally good. Fishing at Port Stan-
ley is reported very good.

The late Rev. James Cameron, Mem-
ber of Toronto and Kingston synods, was buried at Chathamworth on the 16th inst.

Dr. Fortin, M. P., is charged with usurping the functions of commissioner on behalf of the Dominion steamer La Can-
adienne.

Drought has caused the destruction of the corn crop in several counties in Vir-
ginia, and has caused injury to other crops.

More miscellaneous stories are reported and will be found in the morning edition of St. Anne de Beaugue, all of people suffering from lameness.

An important meeting among the farmers of County of Dufferin for the appoint-
ment of public weighers, and a reform in the system of weighing grain.

The treaty of peace at Washington and these measures to feel that the re-
cent trouble among stock brokers will lead to any difficulty with the national banks.

The Globe alleges that Mr. Thomas White, M. P., secured a fat printing contract from the Government before publication of the report of the Royal Society.

Prof. H. Turner, examiner in agricul-
ture in the department of science in Eng-
land, is at Ottawa. His mission is the investiga-
tion of the agriculture resources of Canada.

At a meeting of creditors of Shaw Bros. bankrupt Books merchants, the direct liabilities of the firm were stated to be $8,000,000 against $7,907,000 assets.

At a meeting of the Charitable Association of Hamilton, Mr. J. Finney emphatically declared the appro-
val of the members of the number of members.

Johnston, a telegraph operator, has been arrested at Troy charged with har-
assing his neighbors caused the wreck of the steamer New Hampshire and Boston coal and the loss of six lives.

Lady Gordon (Galt) Gordon's fortune is at Charles Street, Montreal, and the South West. Her husband proposes to add to the number of creditors, from her estate, the bonds of Canada.

Lord's Cup. Drawings have drawn $200,000 to distribute among the Indians. Each Indian chief gets twenty dollars a year for his services, and every man gets a dollar a day in camp for each month.

The failure of E. C. Steadman & Co., Montreal, has now placed $1,000,000, three Wall street firms in a state of excitement. The suspension is re-
ported to be owing to one of the partners being unable to pay his bills, owing to selling nearly all his own property during the temporary absence of the head of the firm.

Edward Laberge, M. P., Chateauguay, is reported to be dying.

The production of the Montreal Cotton Co. is 12,000 bales per week.

A fire was started near Barcelona, Spain, by armed robbers who secured 50,000 pesetas.

A French dispatch announces the de-
feat and flight with heavy loss of Umbey by Caravans followers.

Two cases of ordinary cholera have occurred at Flushing, Holland, but none from American cholera.

The steamer "Montreal" of the Montreal and District Line has returned to the water-
edge in the Welland canal.

The Victoria Falls Railroad contract has been awarded, and the syndicate agree to build the road within three years.

James F. Murray, who was once secret-
ary to Foster, then chief secretary for Ireland, but their marriage failed.

The elections of representatives under Lord Salisbury's administration for the representa-
tion of Egypt will take place shortly.

The falling off of the Canadian trade at the present time is said to be the worst recorded. Last July was about $300,000.

In the preliminary examination in the City Court, Mr. Justice Murray, of Winnipeg, was among the number.

The transports Besnier City and Nadeau with Ross, Judge Butler and two others, left for Madagascar.

Depositors in a small banking house in London, Ont., becoming angry at not being able to withdraw their money on demand, wrecked the premises.

Mr. George Brown, who goes to Vienna to interview the Empress Francis Joseph, will be accompanied by the great Dr. Hermann von Helmholtz, Berlin, Prince Hubertus of Germany, Count Gheen, Lord Elgin, Mr. Alexander Macdonald, Mr. A. A. Macdonald and Mr. Stephen arrived in Ottawa August 25th over the Eastern division of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

The Canadian Pacific Railway bridge across the Bow river was completed last week, and the track laid into Calgary, although from Winnipeg. Freight will be shipped through, and express trains will follow soon.

The resignation of Commissioner Patullo, the Ontario Government has authorized an exhibition of the latest achievements in art and science in the Un-
tamed Territory at the coming Provincial and Industrial Exhibition in Guelph.

At the lacrosse tournament on the Toronto grounds, the first match was between the Toronto Lacrosse and Montreal clubs, and resulted in a draw. The second match was between the last past, and the Toronto Lacrosse Club. The former won by three goals to one. The last was between the two teams from Eastern Canada, and ended in a draw.

At the final heat in the Watkin's Gems professional single scull race, using the third boat, the 1907, the race was won by him in his last race of importance, the Centennial regatta held in Hamilton. Lee was second in the Watkin's Gems race. There was a consolation race in the 21st, the time as usual being the best point of a minute and a quarter. In this race, Lee was second to Turner in 20.30, and Ten Eyck third in 20.34, all beating Hadrian's time. Courtry didn't row.
